ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This is one of, or perhaps the only, class taught about energy transitions at Yale. This is an incredibly interesting topic and if Yale FES wants to be relevant, it *needs* more classes like this.

It gave a good overview of the energy history in America drawing in important case studies through the weekly readings which helps in developing a basis for understanding the interactions of institutions,policies and energy markets. It also gives an insight into the environmental issues that arose during the energy marked energy transitions over the years and how they were,have been and maybe addressed in the future
Thought professor Sabin did a great job facilitating class discussions

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The class presentation could employ students as co-facilitators by them taking a lead in some of the topics outlined in the syllabus.
I think continuing to use and develop the teaching module assignment in future course offerings could be very valuable

Assignments seemed to be random and ad hoc. Not structured in a way that provided a consistent delivery time or expectation level. Difficult to plan in advance for this course due to the weekly changes and requests from the professor.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I have an interest in energy and their markets. The research in energy history provides a good introduction into the energy world by looking at how transitions have occurred over the years and their impact on the social structures as well as the environment. Given I have no academic background in energy other than work experience,it serves as a good foundation course for anyone interested in energy. Additionally,the research paper provides an opportunity for one to develop an argument focusing on energy history and defend the same.This was quite useful as a tool in developing my writing skills
Great historical context in energy. Learned quite a lot about how we might interpret energy history from a US perspective.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The United States,is one of the leading countries in terms of installed energy capacity as well as per capital consumption with several actors in the energy market.I took this course to understand how the country transitioned from one form of energy to the next and how it impacted its industrialization,social structure and legislation and to determine how this compares to other developing countries.
Wanted to examine energy from a new perspective
I have an energy focus in my program.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes the knowledge I gained from the class met and surpassed my expectations.The readings especially the books gave additional information beyond the class syllabus. During the course we were also tasked to developing teaching modules for the history website which I found quite engaging while at the same time challenging.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The course requires a lot of reading (a book per week and blog discussions) and they should be prepared for the same and know how to balance the other subjects as well.
Plenty of writing and a large paper requirement. Plan in advance!
